value.title: PowerBI.Tips - Tutorial - Introduction to DAX Studio - By Darren Gosbell
value.excerpt: DAX Studio is the tool for data model tuning.  Darren Gosbell the creator of DAX Studio will be giving a live demo of his tool.    In this webinar we will be reviewing the following topics:  - What is DAX Studio?  - Why should I use DAX Studio?  - Getting started and connecting DAX Studio to various
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jpZnCHRauPU" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Building a Virtual Relationship in Power BI   Basics of TREATAS DAX Function
value.excerpt: TreatAs is an interesting function with multiple use cases in Power BI. I thought it is good to explain it in a set of videos, the first one here is about what the TreatAs function is and how it can help to build filters and a virtual relationship between two tables. Let's see how you can use this function.
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/YCJjeD8wz5c" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Create a subset of the table in Power BI and add calculations using SELECTCOLUMNS DAX Function
value.excerpt: Previously I explained the AddColumns function as a function that adds one or more columns to the existing table, In this article and video, I'll explain another similar and useful function with slightly different behavior: SelectColumns, and you will learn how you can use it in Power BI and DAX. Download
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/AlROiaxK41c" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Creating Calendar Table in Power BI using DAX Functions
value.excerpt: I have previously explained about using Power Query for creating calendar tables, However, some people still love to do that in DAX. There are a couple of DAX functions which makes the process of creating a calendar table very simple and easy; Calendar() and CalendarAuto(). In this short video, I'll
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/_dd6kiYEm70" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Customers Grouped by the Count of their Orders – Dynamic Segmentation in Power BI Using DAX Measures
value.excerpt: In the previous part of this video, I explained what is the segmentation challenge, when you want to group data based on the aggregated result, and I explained a static method of creating aggregated tables and creating a relationship to the main detailed table. However, the caveat of that method is the
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/bRk0tofVn2c" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: DAX CrossFilter Function in Power BI   Write the Formula both directional but keep the relationship
value.excerpt: If you are familiar with relationships in Power BI, you know that there are scenarios that you may need to change the direction of the relationship to a both-directional. A both-directional relationship comes at a cost, which is mainly the performance and ambiguity of the model. There is a way to write
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/8--Yv18rhyA" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: DAX Measure in the Axis of the Power BI Report
value.excerpt: If you even need to show your DAX measures in a chart without a dimension to slice and dice it, you won’t get a great experience in the visual. In this video, I’ll share a trick that you can use to have a nice visualization like what you see in the above screenshot. Download the file and study more from
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/CRs2CnW7tVU" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Explicit Vs Implicit DAX Measures in Power BI
value.excerpt: Have you ever tried to connect to a Power BI dataset from Excel using Analyze in Excel? if yes, you might have had this experience that your values don’t show in Excel’s Pivot table as values. This is because those values are not explicit measures, they are implicit measures in Power BI. In this article
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/f7g6EvNGClQ" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Parsing Organizational Hierarchy or Chart of Accounts in Power BI with Parent child functions in DAX

value.title: Power BI Modeling Tip   Snapshot Table or DAX Measures
value.excerpt: I often get this question: “Is it better that I create this calculation as a snapshot table in Power Query (or T-SQL, or the data source), or write DAX measures for it?” If you ever had a scenario of creating a report of snapshots, you know what I mean. “Should I have a table for inventory stock on hand
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/fwQuK27F4yg" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Previous Dynamic Period using DAX in Power BI
value.excerpt: Parallel Period is a function that helps you fetching the previous period of a Month, Quarter, or Year. However, if you have a dynamic range of date, and you want to find the previous period of that dynamic selection, then Parallel Period can’t give you the answer. As an example; if the user selected
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Wwo-tY0B9pY" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Substring in DAX   How to get Part of String Field in Power BI Using DAX Expression
value.excerpt: Substring is one of the most common functions in many languages, However, there is no such function in DAX. There is a very simple way of doing it, which I am going to explain in this post. Substring means getting part of a string, for example from "Reza Rad", if I want to get the start starting from
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/WEelCk04dYw" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Creating a calculated table with DAX Studio
value.excerpt: Use DAX Studio to write and test the expression for a calculated table in Power BI. How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/

value.title: How to debug a DAX measure
value.excerpt: Use DAX Studio to run and debug a DAX measure: fix a calculation issue in a more productive environment and then copy the right formula back in Power BI. value.title: Introducing Performance Analyzer in Power BI Desktop
value.excerpt: Performance Analyzer is the first diagnostic tool to find the slower parts of a report. Find the slowest DAX query before starting a deeper investigation using DAX Studio. How to learn DAX: https://www.sqlbi.com/guides/dax/ DAX Studio: https://daxstudio.org/

value.title: Mark as Date Table in Power BI
value.excerpt: Tabular models (including Power BI) require marking the Date table as a date table to get appropriate results with time intelligence calculations. This video explains why this setting is required. Article and download: https://sql.bi/670749
value.featuredContent: <iframe width="800" height="500" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/hrhEjg9yYvE" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

value.title: Optimizing duplicated DAX expressions using variables
value.excerpt: This video describes how to use variables to optimize the performance of DAX expressions containing multiple instances of the same measure or the same sub-expression. There are two related articles and downloads: https://sql.bi/62887/?aff=yt (Optimizing duplicated DAX expressions using variables) https://sql.bi/67786/?aff=yt

value.title: Build a P&L in Power BI Without Any DAX
value.excerpt: This is the third article where I have covered building a P&L in Power BI. My first 2 articles here and here focused on how to use the DAX language to solve some of the common problems with P&L reporting, such as adding sub totals into the visual, % of [...]Read More »

value.title: Introduction to Power BI and DAX
value.excerpt: Back in 2019 I ran a free webinar introducing Power BI and DAX. Many readers of my blog will already be well ahead of this topic, but then again many of you also probably run into people who would benefits from a simple introduction. I have decided to publish the [...]Read More »

value.title: Looking for a great introduction to DAX?
When to use Power Query/M vs Data Modelling/DAX
value.excerpt: Ken Puls and I decided we would do a live stream chat to talk about a topic of interest to Power BI people.  We put out a survey and 75% of the respondents wanted to hear about “when to use Power Query/M vs Data Modelling/DAX”.  It’s a really interesting topic [...]Read More »

value.title: Add DAX calculation groups to Power BI Desktop models
value.excerpt: Learn how you can add many similar measures to your model.

value.title: Calculate Totals for  MTD, QTD and YTD in DAX
value.excerpt: Learn how to quickly use the CALCULATE function to get total from year to date, month to date and quarter to date in Power BI using a Calendar table and time intelligence functions in DAX.
